etymologies: late Old English rodd ‘slender shoot growing on or cut from a tree’, also ‘straight stick or bundle of twigs used to inflict punishment’; probably related to Old Norse rudda ‘club’

definitions: a thin straight bar, especially of wood or metal

examples.text: concrete walls reinforced with steel rods

definitions: a wand or staff as a symbol of office, authority, or power

examples.text: the royal insignia included the ring, the scepter, and the rod

shortDefinitions: wand or staff as symbol of office or power

definitions: a slender straight stick or shoot growing on or cut from a tree or bush

examples.text: the roof is formed of willow and hazel rods woven between willow rafters

shortDefinitions: slender straight stick or shoot growing on or cut from tree

definitions: a stick used for caning or flogging

examples.text: he swung the rod again in a threatening arc

shortDefinitions: stick used for caning or flogging

definitions: the use of a stick as punishment

examples.text: if you'd been my daughter, you'd have felt the rod

shortDefinitions: use of such stick as punishment

examples.text: he hooked an enormous fish which almost pulled the rod from out of his hands
the largest carp ever caught on rod and line in Britain

definitions: a linear measure, especially for land, equal to 51/2 yards (approximately 5.029 m).
a square measure, especially for land, equal to 160th of an acre or 301/4 square yards (approximately 25.29 sq m).

crossReferenceMarkers: Compare with cone (sense 3 of the noun)
definitions: a light-sensitive cell of one of the two types present in large numbers in the retina of the eye, responsible mainly for monochrome vision in poor light.
shortDefinitions: light-sensitive cell of one of two types present in large numbers in retina of eye

phrases.text: rule someone or something with a rod of iron
spare the rod and spoil the child
